utterances: Kaye, thanks very much.

Oh, I actually stayed here and wrote my thesis.
Okay.

We'll look for that on YouTube.
It's another kind of party.
Yeah.
Kaye, thanks very much.
Let's see if we can go now to Danielle(ph), and Danielle is calling us from Tucson, Arizona.
Hello?
Hi.
Hi, how are you?
Very well, thanks.
Thank you for taking my call.
Sure.
Well, I just have kind of a counterpoint to what the guest is saying.
You know, I think in our culture, a lot of people - especially young people that are just coming into college - have been, you know, sheltered or possibly, like, sexually oppressed.

And so I think part of the spring-break phenomenon is that kids really feel like they have the ability to go on spring break and to experiment with all the things that they feel like they're going to be judged about if they do back home.
And so there is that perception that if you go down on spring break, you can really cut loose and anything goes because nobody is going to judge you for it.
And I think that for a lot of people, that is what's bringing them down there, because it's very liberating.
Did you hear that, Meghan Daum, when you were…
I - that is not a point that I have thought about so much until now.
I mean, I guess I would be interested to hear more about how in these universities - maybe some of these kids are feeling oppressed.

I mean, my impression - and, again, these are just, you know, these are my observations and I didn't interview every single person on those beaches, but my feeling was that college, you know, sort of represented 80 percent of this kind of party, you know, atmosphere and, you know, the - you could get 300 percent down on spring break.
But the colleges and universities that tend to be most represented on vacations like these are party schools anyway, typically, you know.
Certainly, when I was in college, no one I knew went on this kind of spring break, it just wasn't part of the culture.

So - but, yeah, I mean, maybe, you know, there might be a sort of - maybe there are schools with, and I'm just speculating, maybe there are religious sort of components that are coming into play here, I don't know.
But I'll have to think about that one.
This caller raised something I - that's new to me.
Danielle, thanks very much.
Thank you.
And here's an e-mail from Susan(ph).
Girls gone wild?
What about the boys?
Are these girls going wild all by themselves?
(Soundbite of laughter)
No, they're not.
The boys, you know, set up an entirely different sort of - not different but they have their own issues.
I saw a lot of almost fear on the faces of some these boys, and there's a real - there's a pecking order, there's competition.
I saw a stage on which there was a sort of girl-and-boy Jell-O wrestling or something, and it involved depicting certain sexual positions.
And the emcee literally threw one of the - threw the guy off the stage and replaced him with a more muscular, better-looking, presumably more-adept-at-this-game guy.
And it was humiliating.
And so I don't - yeah, I think we need to be really clear that this isn't something that's just humiliating for women, this is an equal opportunity humiliation.
And just to - a few seconds left.

What would you…

To some degree.

So the thing that puzzles me the most after all of this is the aversion that people have to the word taxes.
So if you look at it, there are, basically, a few ways to change the distribution of inequality of wealth, taxes is one of them.
But the moment in the U.S.
that you mention the word taxes, people have an incredibly aversive reaction.
And that's something I'm kind of battling with, where this aversion to the word taxes comes from.
I don't yet understand and I hope to understand better.

It's 1964, the start of the anti-communist purges in Indonesia, and a teenager named Adam is hiding in the bushes near his home.
Soldiers arrive in trucks, and they drive up to his front door.
And he watches as they take his father away.
(Reading) They hesitated as they approached the steps going up to the veranda, talking among themselves.
They were too far away; he couldn't hear what they were saying.
Then two of them went up to the house and when they emerged, they had Karl with them.
He was not handcuffed; he followed them slowly, walking to the truck with his uneven gait before climbing up and disappearing under the tarpaulin canopy.
From a distance he looked small, just like them, just like a child, too, only with fair hair and pink skin.
That's Malaysian author Tash Aw.
He's reading from the opening scene of his new novel.
It's called ""Map of the Invinsible World.
